title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: renoir package evaluates chosen machine learning methodology via multiple random sampling approach spanning different training-set sizes. renoir developed thinking teaching/learning abstraction. three main actors renoir framework: learner, evaluator, marker. learner represents learning method assessment linked ?Learner class. evaluator responsible evaluation procedure, .e. assessment performance learner via multiple random sampling, related ?Evaluator class. marker represents final marking evaluation completed, produces features importance; related ?Marker class. example Quick Start help familiarizing concepts.

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: section briefly go main functions, basic operations outputs. First, load renoir package: brief example, decided show functionality renoir classification problem. Let us load set data illustration: command loads input matrix x response vector y saved R data archive. Now want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results example. can specify seed calling ?set.seed. reported Introduction, main actors renoir ?Learner, ?Evaluator ?Marker classes, also main elements need set running analysis.
code: library(renoir) data(binomial_example) #Set a seed for RNG set.seed(   #A seed   seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value   #The kind of RNG to use   kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value   #The kind of Normal generation   normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Let us start ?Learner. ?Learner container different essential elements learning methodology want evaluate. example, focus just three elements, .e. learning procedure, sampling approach, performance metric. first step, need select learning methodology evaluate. list supported methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. example, choose generalized linear model via L1 penalty (lasso) learning method. table, can see default hyperparameter method lambda.
code: #list methods learning.methods = list_supported_learning_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = learning.methods)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now want select sampling procedure use tuning hyperparameter. list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. can see renoir currently supports three sampling scheme: random sampling without replacement, cross-validation. provide options stratified approach, -called ‘proportionate allocation’ attempted maintain proportion strata samples population. hand, random sampling bootstrap allow balancing, meaning proportion strata sample attempted balanced. example, decided tune parameter via stratified 10-fold cross-validation.
code: #list methods sampling.methods = list_supported_sampling_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = sampling.methods)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Finally, want choose performance metric assess models tuning. list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_performance_metrics function call. can see ?list_supported_performance_metrics function reported performance metrics regression classification problems. Let us refine search listing supported metrics binomial response type . can providing resp.type argument function shown . expected, now metrics classification problems listed. Let us select misclassification error (also called classification error rate) performance metric. , overall want train model lasso, tuning hyperparameter lambda via 10-fold cross-validation using misclassification error assess performance models.
code: #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics) #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics(resp.type = "binomial")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Since lasso renoir built-method, can create related ?Learner object single command. used simplified interface constructor, internally creating different needed elements. want fine-grained setting can use alternative interface shown . going details example, however note sampling procedure set creating object class ?Sampler, object class ?Scorer can used define performance metric.
code: #Learner learner <- Learner(   #Learning method   id        = "lasso",    #generalised linear model with penalization   #Response type   resp.type = "binomial",   #Sampling strategy   strata    = y,          #by providing a strata we select the stratified approach   sampling  = "cv",       #cross-validation   k         = 10L,        #10-fold   #Performance metric   score     = "class"     #classification error rate ) #Learner learner <- Learner(   #Trainer   trainer    = Trainer(id = "lasso"),    #generalised linear model with penalization      #Tuner   tuner      = Tuner(     sampler = Sampler(                   #A Sampler contains info for the sampling strategy        method = "cv",                     #cross-validation       k = 10L,                           #10-fold       strata = y                         #by providing a strata we select the stratified approach     )   ),      #Predictor   forecaster = Forecaster(id = "lasso"),      #Performance metric   scorer     = Scorer(                   #A Scorer is used to compute a performance metric     id = "class",                        #classification error rate     resp.type = "binomial"),      #Select one model from a list   selector   = Selector(id = "lasso")      #Record features presence in a model   recorder   = Recorder(id = "lasso")      #Assign a mark to each feature   marker     = Marker(id = "lasso") )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now need set ?Evaluator. Objects class contains infrastructure evaluation procedure, mainly consists sampling strategy adopt metric compute estimate learning method performance. can easily set sampling strategy performance metric creating objects class ?Sampler ?Scorer, respectively shown .
code: #Evaluator evaluator = Evaluator(   #Sampling strategy: stratified random sampling without replacement   sampler = Sampler(               #Sampler object     method = "random",             #random sampling without replacement     k = 10L,                        #k repeats     strata = y,                    #stratified     N = as.integer(length(y))      #population size   ),    #Performance metric   scorer  = Scorer(id = "class"), )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Finally, set ?Marker compute features importance. supported learning method ---box implemented ?Marker, can easily create one command providing learning method class constructor.
code: #Marker marker = Marker(   #Learning method   id = 'lasso',    #Log details   logger = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T) )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now three main actors set, can run analysis. renoir provides single command purpose, ?renoir function. essential required elements ?Learner, ?Evaluator, ?Marker, predictor matrix x, response variable y, response type resp.type. Since chosen learning method one hyperparameter (lambda), also need provide hyperparameters element, supply sequence values used tuning model.
code: #Renoir renoirl = renoir(   #Learn   learner   = learner,                  #a Learner object    #Evaluate   evaluator = evaluator,                #an Evaluator object    #Mark   marker    = marker,                   #a Marker object      #Data for tuning   hyperparameters = list(               #the hyperparameter we     lambda = 10^seq(3, -2, length=100)  #want to tune (for the   ),                                    #lasso is lambda)      #Data for training   x         = x,                        #the predictor matrix   y         = y,                        #the response variable   resp.type = "binomial"                #the response type )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: renoirl list containing two elements class ?Renoir, providing relevant information evaluation procedure. two elements renoir tries select two different final configurations tuning procedure: one configuration (called opt) configuration mean performance chosen repeated sampling procedure optimum value compared across others, e.g. configuration minimal classification error rate; (called 1SE) configuration resulting application -called one standard error rule consists selecting parsimonious model mean performance within one standard error optimum.

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Various methods provided ?Renoir object. example, can produce summary data.frame containing evaluation lasso across different training-set sizes executing ?summary_table command:
code: #get the summary s = summary_table(object = renoirl[[1]])  #print in table DT::datatable(   data = s,                  #data to table   rownames           = F,    #don't show row names   options = list(                lengthMenu = list(       #length of the menu       c(3, 5, 10),           #set 3 as the minimum        c(3, 5, 10)),          #number of shown entries     scrollX = T),            #enable horizontal scrolling   width = "100%",            #width size   height = "auto"            #height size )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: can also visualize results executing ?plot function. example, let us plot results evaluation considering full set data:  circle corresponds performance trained model. mean performance metric (.e. mean misclassification error) computed model performance scores training-set size shown orange line, related confidence intervals drawn bands around mean. red square represents overall best model selected via internal procedure: example, considering misclassification error, renoir selects potential best model choosing model minimal score across models fitted using training-set size showing lowest upper bound 95% CI. example, plot shows quite constant mean score around 0.03 across training-set sizes, indicating good performance classifier. facilitate inspection results, also possible produce interactive plot setting argument interactive = TRUE ?plot command. plot can now zoomed selecting area:  information also shown hoovering plot element. example, try hoover red dot representing best model able see something like :  top row indicates position x y axes: selected model training-set size 681 misclassification error 0.029. Please, note circles slightly jittered position clearer plot, values reported hoovering correct. second row reporting iteration index corresponding model: case, 4th model trained repeated sampling procedure selected best model. supervised screening performed, model contains 9 features. Finally, value lambda resulted tuning used train final model reported.
code: plot(x = renoirl[[1]], measure = "class", set = "full") plot(x = renoirl[[1]], measure = "class", set = "full", interactive = TRUE)

title: REsampliNg methOds for machIne leaRning
text: renoir R package providing analytical framework robust reproducible machine learning analyses. idea behind renoir implement scalable, modular open-source software standardised application machine learning techniques high-dimensional data.  renoir allows robust estimation true error learning methodology implementing multiple random-sampling approach spanning different training-set sizes, computing mean performance metrics confidence intervals. Appropriate unsupervised pre-processing strategies initial dimensionality reduction integrated facilitate correct application part process. considered train-set size, evaluation learning methodology based training testing models multiple independent train/test sets data generated via random sampling, bootstrapping k-fold cross-validation, training set used build models, left-set assess performance. computed measures assessment used obtain estimate mean performance related 95% confidence interval. Different supervised feature screening strategies implemented incorporated learning steps, .e. training/tuning models. Regression classification problems binomial data currently supported.

title: REsampliNg methOds for machIne leaRning
text: Install latest development version GitHub (requires devtools package):
code: if (!require("devtools")) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::install_github("alexb-84-dev/renoir", dependencies = TRUE, build_vignettes = FALSE)

title: Absolute Error — absolute_error
text: absolute error (AE) based absolute values defined $$AE(y_{},\hat{y}_{}) = \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observed data multiple output values weights provided, error weighted. $$wAE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} w_{j}} w * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(w_{j}\) weighting factor assigned \(j\)-th response. best possible score zero.

title: Absolute Percentage Error — absolute_percentage_error
text: absolute percentage error (APE) based absolute values. absolute percentage error defined $$APE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value, \(\epsilon\) arbitrary positive small number used avoid division zero. response multiple output values weights provided, error weighted. $$wAPE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{w * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(w\) vector \(n\) elements, \(w_{j}\) weighting factor assigned \(j\)-th response. best possible score zero.

title: Confidence Interval — ci

title: Confidence Interval — ci
text: confidence interval provides additional information variability point estimate generally defined $$CI = estimate \pm \textit{margin error} = estimate \pm \textit{critical value} \times \textit{standard error}$$ \(\textit{estimate}\) sample statistic estimating population parameter interest; \(\textit{critical value}\) value based sampling distribution estimate desired confidence level; \(\textit{standard error}\) standard deviation point estimate. Since estimates different samples population can different, estimate can seen random variable distribution. Given interested estimate specific sample rather want draw conclusions population, confidence interval can used obtain information population parameter. Beware interpretation. CI telling us population parameter inside range. fact, generally know population parameter, know interval contains . However, know certain number intervals (confidence level, e.g. 95%) formed way contain parameter.

title: F1 Score — f1_score
text: F1 score measure accuracy computed harmonic mean precision recall: $$F_{1} = \frac{2}{precision^{-1} + recall^{-1}} = 2\frac{precision \times recall}{precision + recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + \frac{1}{2}(FP + FN)}$$ highest possible value 1.0, indicating perfect precision recall. lowest possible value 0. specific case F-beta score, beta = 1

title: Features Importance — features_importance
text: object list renoir.tat objects best.config configuration consider recruitment.term whether use binary variable (presence = 0 presence = 1) multiplied sign coefficient, use directly coefficient feature computation significance score. set set data used computation accuracy measures. example, set = "test.set" accuracy measures used computation features importance ones calculated test set.

title: Features Importance — features_importance
text: single response, list vectors, vector associate accuracy measure, contains measures significance feature. multi-response, list lists.

title: Features Importance — features_importance
text: feature significance score computed sum normalised coefficient feature model multiplied weight model. formula -th feature : $$score_{} = \frac{1}{s}\sum_{j=1}^{n} weight_{j}*coefficient_{j} ,$$ \(n\) total number models computed across different training set sizes, \(coefficient_{j}\) normalised coefficient (.e. coefficient feature divided maximum absolute value coefficients features model value ranging \([-1,1]\)), \(s\) sum weights. \(weight\) model obtained dividing multiplicative inverse squared prediction error model max value across models, models better prediction accuracy higher weight: $$weight_{j} = \frac{w_{j}}{w_{best}},$$ \(w_{j}\) multiplicative inverse squared prediction error model: $$w_{j} = \frac{1}{err_{j}^2},$$ $$w_{best} = \max{w_{1},...,w_{j},...,w_{n}}.$$ Note auc accuracy measure, consider prediction error \(err_{j} = 1 - auc_{j}\). selecting use = "presence", \(coefficient_{j}\) term computation significance score exchanged \(presence_{j}*sign_{j}\), \(presence_{j}\) stands presence feature j-th model \(sign_{j}\) sign coefficient -th feature j-th model.

title: Linear model for series of arrays — limma
text: x matrix-like data object containing log-ratios log-expression values series arrays, rows corresponding genes columns samples. design design matrix microarray experiment, rows corresponding arrays columns coefficients estimated. Defaults unit vector meaning arrays treated replicates. method fitting method; "ls" least squares "robust" robust regression contrasts numeric matrix rows corresponding coefficients fit columns containing contrasts. May vector one contrast. assay.type Assay type: "array" microarray data, "seq" sequencing data proportion numeric value 0 1, assumed proportion genes differentially expressed coef column number column name specifying coefficient contrast linear model interest. topTable, can also vector column subscripts, case gene ranking F-statistic set contrasts. coef single value, moderated t-statistics p-values coefficient contrast used. coef takes two values, moderated F-statistics set coefficients contrasts used. coef left NULL, coefficients contrasts fitted model used, except coefficient named (Intercept) removed. number maximum number genes list adjust.method method used adjust p-values multiple testing. Options, increasing conservatism, include "none", "BH", "" "holm" p.value cutoff value adjusted p-value top.table.sort.character string specifying statistic rank genes . Possible values topTable "logFC", "AveExpr", "t", "P", "p", "B" "none". (Permitted synonyms "M" "logFC", "" "Amean" "AveExpr", "T" "t" "p" "P".) plotVenn logical, whether plot Venn diagram showing numbers genes signifcant comparison outdir output directory logger Logger warningsFile path warning file use. logFile path log file use.

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: mean absolute error (MAE) measure errors based absolute values. treats small large errors equally less sensitive outliers compared measures (e.g. MSE). MAE estimated n observations defined $$MAE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMAE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output eps arbitrary positive small number, used correct MAPE formula avoid division zero rweights response weights

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: mean absolute percentage error, positive double vector positive double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) measure errors based relative absolute values. MAPE estimated *n* observations defined $$MAPE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value, \(\epsilon\) arbitrary positive small number used avoid division zero. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute percentage error computed $$wMAPE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: mean squared error (MSE) measure errors based squared losses. Small large errors treated equally, large errors heavily weighted small ones thus skewing measure. sensitive outliers compared measures (e.g. MAE). MSE estimated *n* observations defined $$MSE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMSE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Squared Logarithmic Error — mean_squared_log_error
text: mean squared logarithmic error (MSLE) measure errors based squared logarithmic losses. metric commonly preferred (e.g. MSE) -predicted estimates penalised -predicted ones. Huge differences predicted true values penalised (huge numbers). MSLE estimated n observations defined $$MSLE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (log(1 + y_{}) - log(1 + \hat{y}_{}))^{2}$$ \(log\) natural logarithm, \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMSLE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (log(1 + y_{}) - log(1 + \hat{y}_{}))^{2}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: R squared — r2_score
text: R squared score, double vector double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: R squared — r2_score
text: coefficient determination (R squared) measure proportion variance dependent variable explained independent variables. R2 estimated n observations defined $$R^{2}(y,\hat{y}) = 1 - \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \bar{y})^{2}}$$ \(\bar{y}\) mean observed data, \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted R squared computed $$wR^{2}(w,y,\hat{y}) = 1 - \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}*(y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}*(y_{} - \bar{y})^{2}}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score one.

title: R squared — r2_score
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Root-Mean-Square Error — root_mean_squared_error
text: root-mean-square error (RMSE) measure errors based squared losses. defined squared root mean_squared_error: $$RMSE(y,\hat{y}) = \sqrt{MSE(y,\hat{y})} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}$$ observation weights provided, weighted root mean squared error computed $$wRMSE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \sqrt{wMSE(w,y,\hat{y})} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}$$ function shortcut mean_squared_error(root = TRUE, ...).

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: length-one numeric vector.

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: Currently, implementation considering eventual stratification estimate variance. also assume measurements (.e. x) drawn population variance \(V(x_{}) = \sigma_{x}^2\). variance sample mean computed $$\hat{\sigma}_{W}^{2} = V(\frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}x_{}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}) = \frac{1}{(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{})^2} V(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}x_{}) = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}^2}{(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{})^2} \sigma_{x}^2$$ different ways estimate variance x (\(\sigma_{x}^2\)). use common formula unbiased estimator unweighted data $$s_{x}^2 = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} (x_{} - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}$$

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
